title: Projects
text:
Primary lifecourse GWAS meta analysis
This is the primary project of the lifecourse GWAS consortium. The aim is to perform a meta analysis of GWAS data from multiple cohorts to identify genetic variants associated with a range of traits across the lifecourse.

title: The Lifecourse GWAS consortium
text: Many adverse health outcomes in later life may be influenced by processes experienced throughout one’s lifetime. The Lifecourse GWAS consortium was established by researchers at the MRC Integrative Epidemiology Unit (University of Bristol) to gain a better understanding of how exposures at different stages in the lifecourse influence later life health outcomes.

title: The Lifecourse GWAS consortium
text:
Current status
We are currently recruiting studies to join the Consortium. Please contact lifecourse-gwas-group@bristol.ac.uk if you are interested in being involved.

title: The Lifecourse GWAS consortium
text:
Executive committee and Core group
The executive committee has been set-up to provide oversight and review the development of the Lifecourse GWAS consortium. The finalised list of executive committee members is TBC.
The core research group comprises:
Dr. Grace Power, Prof. Gibran Hemani, Dr. Eleanor Sanderson, Dr. Genevieve Leyden and Dr. David Carslake

title: The Lifecourse GWAS consortium
text:
Contact information
To get in touch please email lifecourse-gwas-group@bristol.ac.uk



MRC IEU and University of Bristol logos

title: The Lifecourse GWAS consortium
text:
Aims and Objectives
Inherited genetic variants may have different effects on some exposures across the lifecourse (within a population). The primary aim of this study is to generate a comprehensive resource of age-stratified genome-wide association studies (GWAS) which will be instrumental in conducting Mendelian randomization (MR) analyses of exposures at distinct lifecourse stages on later life outcomes.
